titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: Today Davidson leaves Lambeth in order that Lang may enter. The tradition of Scottish canniness and servility is to continue. No principle is to be too boldly asserted: & no interest too rashly challenged. The "opportunism" that postpones issues, & clutches at chances has to handle the gravest situation that has faced the Church of England since the Restoration.
writes about the new Primate in the '
', crediting him with high courage, & a large wisdom. But the evidences of both lie in the future. The policy of seeking genuine autonomy within the Establishment – which I suppose to be
's – will serve well enough to dispense with any immediate steps to "

" of the Church, but cannot possibly be regarded as a practicable policy. Autonomy could not consist with the Crown nomination of Bishops, nor with the final appellant jurisdiction, nor with the supremacy of Parliament. It could only mean Disestablishment without Disendowment: and that is a policy which commands acceptance in no quarter of the political world. I cannot regard it as sincerely contemplated by so intelligent a Primate.

I left Oxford at 10.8 a.m., and travelled to Paddington in company with the Bishop of Oxford. I drove to the Athenaeum, and then went to the hairdresser. After lunching at the Club, I proceeded to Westminster for the meeting of the Assembly.

expressed great disgust at Inge's treatment of his Bishop: and, indeed, I think it is really indefensible. After all,
owes to his Bishop whatever deference is implied in 'canonical obedience'.
I dined in Park Lane. It was a very interesting party viz: M
Neville Chamberlain, Lady Nunbarnholme, Lord Hardinge, M
Tanner. Conversation was animated, discursive, and well–sustained. Lady N. repeated to me the statement about the ill state of Oxford morals, which, on the authority of
, I had contradicted to the Bishop of Blomfontein. She was very positive about it in spite of my protest. I wonder what the source of this rumour really is.
